titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Wasted the forenoon, loitering in the garden, and budding peach and pear-trees— Mr: Bayley was here— A man who has invented a convenient door-hinge, for which he is solliciting a patent— I gave him a letter for Mr: Sheldon— Captn: Beale was here, to agree upon the meeting of the Neponset-Bridge Proprietors at Boston to-morrow.— Mr: T. Greenleaf junr: here in the Evening— Finished the fair copy of my 10th: lecture— George came home this afternoon; but John still remains at my father’s.

2. Went to Boston this morning with Mrs: Adams, and we took George with us— Dined at Dr: Welsh’s— Meeting of the Proprietors of Neponset Bridge at 11. At Whitcomb’s— Only Captn: Beale—Mr: Quincy—Mr: Foster and myself, present with Mr: Shaw the Clerk— The Officers of the year were chosen, and we adjourned the meeting to the 23d. at 3. P.M. to meet at the Bridge.— The Books and Papers of the Company, are in great disorder— One of the great inconveniences of Companies is that there is no person who specially attends to their regular periodical acts— I have observed at the American Academy, the convenience of having some sensible image to remind the members of their regulations— At their annual meetings they choose their Officers— They have boxes to collect the votes; and on each box the name of the Officer— But not having a box for the annual Committee of Publications, they have frequently forgotten to elect them— At the last annual meeting therefore I proposed to Dr: Lathrop to have a box for that Committee, which he promised— If he procures it, their election will not again be neglected— This day was so rainy that I could do scarcely any other business, excepting that of the Company’s Meeting— Called at the Fire and Marine Insurance Office— No Dividend— Returned to Quincy this Evening, with continual bad weather—

3. Incessant rain through the night, and almost the whole of this day. I was confined to the house, yet wasted the time, as I have all the preceding days— Perpetual petty avocations snatch away all my time, and at the close of the day, I find I have done nothing, without knowing how the hours have slip’d away.— I finished the first sketch of my 11th: Lecture.

4. Mrs: Adams and Caroline went to Mrs: Quincy’s this afternoon— I called at the beginning of the Evening at my father’s— I was this day again as attentive to my business as my situation will allow, and did not absolutely lose the whole day— I began the fair copy of my 11th: lecture, and the first sketch of the 12th:— Of the former I wrote but little; for I must change all the arrangement, and nearly write the whole lecture over again.

5. Wrote a little in the forenoon, and accomplished my afternoon’s task, which I have reduced from three to two pages of fair copy— Now modelling entirely the lecture upon which I am now engaged two pages is as much as I can accomplish at a sitting— I went to my father’s early in the Evening— My brother came to my house— I return’d with Mrs: Cranch— Finished reading Cumberland’s Memoirs.

6. All the morning engaged in budding pear-trees, which took me from my business— In the afternoon wrote on my 11th: lecture, which I am shaping a little more to my satisfaction— Walk’d to my father’s in the Evening— Mr: T. Greenleaf junr: was here— Our Maid Sally again very ill—

7. Heard Mr: Thacher of Dedham the whole day— We all dined at my father’s— The day was again foul and rainy— In the Evening I read the first Chapter of the Voyages d’Anacharsis—Vol: 2. to the Ladies. And in the afternoon wrote my usual portion.
8. This day for the first time since I came here, I employed my whole time as I ought— My Brother dined with us— In the Evening the Ladies went to a Ball, and I spent it with my father—

9. Mrs: Adams and Caroline walk’d this morning, to return their visits— Spent the Evening at Mr: D. Greenleaf’s— Had a severe thunder shower late in the Evening— Read to the Ladies Pope’s Translation of the Odyssey—Book 1.— Finished Lecture 11.

11. I went into Boston this morning to make arrangements respecting my house which Mr: Bradford is to leave next week— I saw him, and also Mr: Shaw, and Mr: Baldwin upon them? it— Mr: Bradford now talks of remaining in the house untill the Spring. But is to give his final answer to-morrow— I also received the two fire-policies, at the Mutual-fire Insurance Company— Dined with Mr: J. Gardner; and returned in the Stage to Quincy at Night— Found Mr: T. Greenleaf junr: here.
10. (Day Transposed.)— My father called at my house this Morning— I employed much of it in the Garden— Too much for my studies. With the Ladies in the Evening at Mrs: T. Greenleaf’s—

12. Rain, the greatest part of the day, which confined me at home— Walk’d however in the Evening— My youngest child, John, quite unwell this afternoon—and had a high fever at Night— Read—Barrow’s Lectures—Pope’s Odyssey IV—and Moore’s Poems.

13. John was quite ill with a violent fever all Night, but appeared to be much better through the course of the day. Rain all the Morning, and a heavy thunder shower— Cleared at Noon— Mr: Quincy was here in the afternoon— George could not go to school— The innumerable interruptions of my business prevented me from writing much— I called at my father’s in the Evening— After returning, read Pope’s Odyssey V. to the Ladies.

14. Mr: S. A. Otis and his family called here on their return from a visit to Plymouth— And they went to my father’s— Heard Mr: Whitney the whole day— I was at my father’s this afternoon, and untill the Evening— Life of Chillingworth in the Biographia Britannica. John better this day, but still feverish.

15. My brother went to Dedham, & his wife to Haverhill.— Mr: & Mrs: Harper— Mrs: Caton and her two daughters— Mr: Davis, Mr: Bowdoin, Mr: Rogers, Mr: W. Sullivan and Mr: Shaw were here this morning— In the Evening we were at Mr: Miller’s— My Mother was suddenly seized, and very ill this afternoon— John was again very unwell this Evening; after we came from Mr: Miller’s, I was reading in the 6th: Book of the Odyssey, when John alarmed us by waking from sleep with a violent shriek— He had some fever again— But after fully awaking complained not of any pain—he had afterwards a quiet night.

16. I have taught George to repeat by heart La Fontaine’s first Fable—he now says it perfectly— I explained to him the meaning of the fable. When I had finished he asked me if the Ant did not give the Grasshopper some of the Corn she wanted— I told him no— “Then she was a very bad Ant” said he— This was the natural comment of sensibility, and I think it shews the moral of that fable to be defective— I went to see my Mother this forenoon, and found her unwell; though a little better than she was yesterday.— I was there again last Night, and Caroline spent the afternoon there— I began the first draught of my 13th: lecture.

17. John continues to have some fever, though otherwise he appears to be not unwell— This day the Summer return’d in all its heat— My father and Mother called here this morning— I spent the day and Evening at home, but neither wrote nor read much— My mode of existence is fatal to all attempt at composition.

18. Caroline went into Boston with Mr: T. Greenleaf junr: and returned at Night— We intended also to have gone in, but Mrs: Adams finally concluded not to go— She is herself very unwell; and the child continues to have a fever— In the afternoon I went down to my father’s for about an hour.— The Doctor was here twice this day— I read one or two of Barrow’s Lectures, and a Chapter or two of Rabelais, whose language I now understand tolerably well, but to whose wit I still want a key.

19. John still has some thing of a fever but appears to be recovering— I have made for George an English imitation of la Fontaine’s first fable— After spending the day as usual with perpetual avocations, and very little of my proper business, I went to my father’s and spent an hour in the Evening—

20. My Mother and Aunt Smith were here this afternoon to tea— John is much better, though not yet perfectly well— George too was unwell and detained from School— I spent as usual in the Evening an hour at my father’s— He had return’d from Dr: Holbrook’s at Milton where he dined— My brother also returned from Dedham.

21. Heard Mr: Whitney of Hingham the whole day— I took George with me— Dined at my father’s— My brother came home with me in the afternoon— In the evening we walk’d to my father’s, where we spent half an hour, and called at Mr: Cranch’s— John is not yet perfectly recovered—

22. Sent George alone to School—(for the first time.) Mrs: Adams and Caroline rode out this afternoon, and took John with them— In the Evening I called at my father’s— Mr: T. Greenleaf junr: was here— I finished the first draught of my 13th: lecture and began the 14th:— Read the 6th: Book of Pope’s Odyssey to the Ladies—and two of Barrow’s Lectures—

23. This afternoon I attended the adjourned meeting of the Proprietors of Neponsit Bridge; when we adopted a new set of Regulations; we had also a meeting of the Directors and Officers were chosen— Mr: Miller Mr: Quincy and myself were the only Directors present— Mr: Quincy took me to my father’s— He and my mother went this afternoon to Scituate— Mrs: Adams & Caroline road this afternoon— I wrote less than usual—

24. Besides all my other occupations, I now spend too much of my time in my Garden, where I have undertaken to raise various fruits from the seed, stone and nut— I have already succeeded in obtaining a few Apples—Pears—Plumbs—Cherries—Peaches—and American Walnuts— Besides a couple of Oaks— But this is only the third Autumn since I first began, and I lose a great proportion of my seeds and young trees, from ignorance how to manage them— This evening I went to my father’s, and found him just return’d from Scituate— After I came home, I read the 7th: Book of Pope’s Odyssey— The subject of my present lecture, I find easier than any I have been engaged in for several weeks; but my progress is still slow.

25. A small company of Ladies and Gentlemen were here this afternoon at tea— My mother being unwell did not come— Mrs: Adams is also quite unwell— Caroline was to have gone this morning to Boston; but finally determined to stay— I was employed alternately in my garden, and at my writing.
26. Confined at home the greater part of the day, by the weather— Mrs: Cranch spent the afternoon here— In the Evening, I read to the Ladies the 8th: Book of Pope’s Odyssey—

div.p: 27. Went to Boston with Mrs: Adams this morning— I proceeded immediately to Cambridge— Enquired of President Webber (whom I found in the Philosophy Chamber, examining a scholar for admission) whether the arrangements were made, by which I should be obliged to attend but once a week at Cambridge— He said they were not;—but they should be completed, as soon as possible— In the mean time I must go, both Thursday’s and Friday’s— The lectures are however to be delivered at 10. in the morning— I called at Dr: Waterhouse’s—Mr: Gannett’s—Mr: Moore’s—& Mr: Watson’s— Enquired respecting the House that was Mr: Brattle’s— That of Mr: Pearson—and that of Mr: Moore— Could obtain no satisfactory answer respecting either— Return’d to Boston— Dined at Whitcomb’s— Churchill was there, and after dinner proposed to borrow money of me, for which he offerr’d me 10 per Cent, and substantial security— I told him truly that all the spare property I had, was placed at less profit and with more safety— Churchill has the credit of living upon Usury. I never did, and never Will— I saw Mr: Gardner who talks of leaving my house; but I think he will remain— About 5 in the afternoon I call’d for Mrs: Adams at Dr: Welsh’s, where she had dined, and we returned to Quincy— Found Mr: T. Greenleaf junr: at our house.

28. Heard Mr: Whitney the whole day— Went with all my family to my father’s this afternoon— We returned early in the Evening— Read the 9th: Book of Pope’s Odyssey to the Ladies— I found this afternoon in my father’s garden, that three or four young walnut trees, of those which I planted two years ago, have within these few days first come up— The walnut I think grows only in May, June and July— The Apple—Pear—and Plumb, grow twice in the Summer— The Peach all Summer through— The Cherry, untill the beginning of this month.

29. Mrs: Adams and Caroline went this afternoon to Mrs: Quincy’s on a visit— In the evening I called for half an hour at my father’s, who had been here in the morning— After returning I read the 10th: Book of the Odyssey.

30. I was confined at home the greater part of the day, by the weather which was foul— I finished the first draught of my fourteenth, and began the 15th: lecture; but wrote less than usual; and less to my own satisfaction— My application is so much remitted that the effect corresponded in the depreciation of my work.

Day. Rise about 6. Read 3 Chapters in the Greek Testament, and three in the English Bible— Dig and labour in my garden, a couple of hours— Breakfast— Hear George read French— Stroll about the Garden another hour. Write my lectures untill 1 or 2. P.M— Dine— Hear George again— Write on my lectures again untill dark. Walk to my father’s— Pass an hour there and return— Read to the Ladies an hour— Sup; and at 10 or 11. retire to bed— One day in the week I go in to Boston—and Sundays, I intermit from all Application— I am very much dissatisfied with my own indolence— Yet have not resolution and fortitude to reform— At least my health does not suffer from too laborious study.
